articles.headline: Top Lawyer, Under Fire, May Depart
articles.snippet: William S. Lerach, one of the most powerful securities class-action lawyers in the nation, is considering plans to leave the law firm he founded three years ago.
articles.abstract: William S. Lerach, one of the most powerful securities class-action lawyers in the nation, is considering plans to leave the law firm he founded three years ago.
articles.lead_paragraph: William S. Lerach, one of the most powerful securities class-action lawyers in the nation, is considering plans to leave the law firm he founded three years ago.

articles.headline: One Place Where Obama Goes Elbow to Elbow
articles.snippet: Senator Barack Obama is a wily player of pickup basketball, a game with unspoken rules and lots of elbows.
articles.abstract: Senator Barack Obama is a wily player of pickup basketball, a game with unspoken rules and lots of elbows.
articles.lead_paragraph: Last Christmas, Senator Barack Obama flew to Hawaii to contemplate a presidential bid in the peace of his childhood home. But there, on a humid playground near Waikiki Beach, he found himself being roughed up by some of his best friends. It was the third and final game of the group’s annual three-on-three basketball showdown, and with the score nearly tied, things were getting dirty.

articles.headline: What Seller Wants a Low Price?
articles.snippet: The S.E.C. is considering whether a different kind of auction will be allowed to set values on company income statements.
articles.abstract: The S.E.C. is considering whether a different kind of auction will be allowed to set values on company income statements.
articles.lead_paragraph: Can you imagine an auction house bragging to sellers about the low prices at its auctions? Perhaps this would be the pitch:

articles.headline: Dow Jones Says It Will Consider Options for Sale
articles.snippet: The decision represents an about-face for both the company and Rupert Murdoch’s bid and could end more than a century of family ownership.
articles.abstract: The decision represents an about-face for both the company and Rupert Murdoch’s bid and could end more than a century of family ownership.
articles.lead_paragraph: The family that controls Dow Jones & Company, publisher of The Wall Street Journal, announced yesterday that it would consider selling the company, ending more than a century of family ownership.
articles.byline: By ANDREW ROSS SORKIN and RICHARD PÉREZ-PEÑA

articles.headline: A Growing Demand for the Rare American Imam
articles.snippet: Some Muslim congregations are seeking native imams who can discuss issues that seem relevant to young people.
articles.abstract: Some Muslim congregations are seeking native imams who can discuss issues that seem relevant to young people.
articles.lead_paragraph: MISSION VIEJO, Calif. — Sheik Yassir Fazaga regularly uses a standard American calendar to provide inspiration for his weekly Friday sermon.

articles.headline: Big Investors Jumping Back Into Shaky Home Loans
articles.snippet: Private equity is swooping in and taking over the subprime mortgage business, seeing opportunity amid the wreckage.
articles.abstract: Private equity is swooping in and taking over the subprime mortgage business, seeing opportunity amid the wreckage.
articles.lead_paragraph: The subprime mortgage business is in tatters: loan volume is plummeting, defaults are rising and some of the biggest lenders have cut back or shut down.
articles.byline: By Vikas Bajaj and Julie Creswell

articles.headline: Google Zooms In Too Close for Some
articles.snippet: A new online feature of Google Maps called Street View is stirring up a debate over privacy concerns on the Web.
articles.abstract: A new online feature of Google Maps called Street View is stirring up a debate over privacy concerns on the Web.
articles.lead_paragraph: OAKLAND, Calif., May 31 — For Mary Kalin-Casey, it was never about her cat.

articles.headline: Where Now, for the Wind?
articles.snippet: The staying power of wind energy companies is dependent on tax benefits from the capricious hands of lawmakers in Congress.
articles.abstract: The staying power of wind energy companies is dependent on tax benefits from the capricious hands of lawmakers in Congress.
articles.lead_paragraph: WINGATE, Tex. — If he could have ever seen the FPL Group’s new wind farm here, Don Quixote would have certainly fallen off his horse.
